oppose.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to disagree with something such as a plan or idea and try to prevent it from happening or succeeding
oppose.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Congress is continuing to oppose the president’s health care budget.
oppose.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to fight or compete against another person or group in a battle, competition, or election
oppose.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: He is opposed by two other candidates.
oppose.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: oppose
to think that a plan or idea is wrong, and to try to prevent it from happening or succeeding
Hundreds of people wrote to oppose the scheme.
The other parties opposed the bill.
be against something/be opposed to something
to think that something is wrong and should not be allowed
I used to be against the death penalty.
Most people are opposed to the privatization of the city’s public transportation system.
not agree with something
to think that something is wrong
I don’t agree with training animals for entertainment.
to say or feel that something is wrong
No one objected to the proposals.
She strongly objects to being told what to do.
resist
to try to prevent a change from happening, or prevent yourself from being forced to do something
People often resist change, when they have been used to doing things in a certain way for a long time.
She resisted all attempts to teach her how to cook.
anti-
opposed to something – used in adjectives
anti-war protesters
an anti-slavery movement
oppose.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to disagree with a plan or idea and try to prevent it from happening
oppose.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Three members of the board opposed the motion.
Several leading City investors had opposed the Bank of England’s proposals.
